title: 111_s1714
content:
The Act is titled the "Open College Textbook Act of 2009" and includes findings. The growth of the Internet has enabled the creation and sharing of open educational resources. The President has proposed a significant Federal investment in online open-source courses for community colleges to make learning more accessible and affordable. The goal is to have the highest college graduation rate in the world by 2020. Over 80% of future jobs will require postsecondary education, yet only 36% of 18- to 24-year-olds are currently enrolled. The high cost of college textbooks remains a challenge. The high cost of college textbooks is a barrier for many students, with 200,000 qualified students not enrolling in college each year due to cost. On average, students spent $805 to $1,229 on books and supplies in the 2007-2008 academic year. Providing open textbooks for free could lower costs and improve learning by creating more flexible and accessible course materials. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

Director - Director of the National Science Foundation.
Institution of higher education - Defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965.
Open license - Grants public access to copyrighted material.
Open textbook - Electronic course materials for higher education under an open license.
Secretary - Secretary of Education. The Secretary is authorized to award grants to eligible entities for creating open textbooks. Eligible entities include institutions of higher education, professors, and organizations. Grants are for 1 year and applications are required. Each eligible entity seeking a grant must submit an application to the Secretary with project details, quality review plans, access strategies, and distribution plans for open textbooks in postsecondary courses. The Secretary awards grants for open textbooks in postsecondary courses, with special consideration for high-quality, marketable textbooks that align with high enrollment courses and are easily used by faculty. An eligible entity receiving a grant must create, update, or adapt open textbooks for postsecondary coursework. The textbooks must be licensed through an open license for accessibility. The open textbooks created with grant funding must be posted on an accessible website for free public access and can be downloaded, redistributed, and altered. The Secretary will establish a peer review process to ensure quality and accuracy of the textbooks. Upon completion of a project supported under this section, the eligible entity must submit a report to the Secretary detailing all project costs, including volunteer labor and institutional capital. $15,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010, with additional funding for the following 5 years. SEC. 5. LICENSING MATERIALS WITH A FEDERAL CONNECTION. Educational materials created through Federal grants must be licensed under an open license and made freely accessible to the public online. Congress encourages higher education institutions to consider open textbooks within academic freedom principles. The Secretary must report on open textbooks created, adopted, and savings generated by September 30, 2015.
